content.description: The Wo Project involves a series of thin moves on the face moving right to better holds on the edge/topout.
content.location: This is on the face between the two boulders...on a large boulder.

content.description: Start on the The Wo Project, but instead of topping out the arete to the right, continue up left, and use good, slopey slots to top the high lip of the boulder. (Edit) after climbing some more v8’s and a v9 I’ve decided to downgrade it from a v9- to a v8. It’s just about the same difficulty as other v8’s I’ve tried. The crux is maybe a v4-5 move which is in line with v8. IMO, I think the wo project should be v8- or v7+ But it’s not my climb so I can’t change it
content.location: In the middle of two boulders, start low on both sides of a small block on the tallest boulder.

content.description: Do a big reach out to the left arete. You either can go high for taller people or low. Use some sidepulls closer to the arete for your right hand. The hardest part is finding the crimps to mantel up to the top. This is where you need a spotter, there are some rocks below that will hurt.
content.location: Start near the start of the Wo Project. There is a nice set of sidepulls and poor feet below.

content.description: Begin with a tough start position (your right hand in a dished sidepull and your left hand down low on a small, crimpy flake just above knee level) into a left hand move up to a crimp, and climb straight up over the bulge. The crack on the left is off as well as the arete to the right.
content.location: It is on the slab on the side of the boulder facing Lake Ave.

content.description: The front of the boulder is a nice slab with a good crack on the back. There are lots of options, and it is a good warm-up boulder.
content.location: This is on the boulder just behind the third base line.

content.description: The start is a small crimp for your left hand and a low, sidepull jug on the arete, with a good right foot hold underneath. Bump your right hand to another sidepull on the arete. Stand up, and reach left out to the crimp rail. Match on the rail, and pull up to the right to a big flake (there is a crimp below if needed). Move your left hand up to a crimp on the crack, then top out. The crux is getting the feet set correctly for the flake at the top.
content.protection: 2 pads - there are some sketchy rocks underneath.
content.location: It is trail side to the right of “The Fix.”

content.description: This is a fun problem and Noah's first FA.
content.location: This ascends the edge facing the trail on the left boulder.

content.description: This crack is ok in small amounts.
content.location: It is on the left side of the large boulder with the lake at your back.

content.description: Start on two large sidepulls, toe/heel hook on the left starting hold, then reach and cross to a small crimp that's up and to the right of the starting holds. Reach out to the Chicken Chin Dyno start, walk your feet across, then do the Chicken Chin Dyno.Alternate beta: reach right hand up to the small crimp, and rose move to the start of Chicken Chin Dyno or full dyno to the start of Chicken Chin Dyno.
content.location: Start on the two large sidepull jugs to the left of Chicken Chin Dyno.

content.description: The hardest part of this is mantel 10 feet up.
content.location: From trailside, this is the edge on the large boulder across from Noah's Arete .

content.description: Chicken Slab has no crux, it is just a slab.
content.location: This is on the inside of crack opposite The Wo Project.

content.description: Start on the low jug on the right side of the bulge below the chicken chin. Go to the sloping crimp out and left. Heel hook the starting jug, and work your way around the sloping edge of the bulge to the start of the chicken chin dyno. Finish by climbing the chicken chin dyno. The crux is definitely sticking the move to the starting jug of the dyno.
content.location: Facing the chicken chin, the starting jug is low and right.

content.description: Start on the obvious jug at head level on the left face of the Chicken Chin Boulder. Using high feet, dyno to the crimp in the dish on the left side of the chicken chin. Top out using a high left foot.
content.location: Start on the left face, opposite of the chicken chin.

content.description: Pulling out of roof is the hardest part on this problem.
content.location: Start on the trail side, traverse left under the roof, and then top out.

content.description: There is a 15 foot high, split boulder in the trails behind Tivnan Field (across from Lake Park). All but one of the routes is in the V0-V3 range, then the other is V8+. It is not a bad little spot if you want something quick and close while you're in the Worcester area. In addition, there is a 10 foot high boulder just behind the ball field which has some good moderate routes.
